I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on proposed loans to 
the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka for the additional financing of the Northern Road 
Connectivity Project.1 The report also describes proposed change in the associated technical 
assistance  (TA)  for  Capacity  Development  of  Northern  Provincial  Road  Development 
Department (NPRDD),2 and if the Board approves the proposed loans, I, acting under the 
authority delegated to me by the Board, will approve the change in the TA. 
 
2.  The project, together with the original project, will improve the road connectivity in the 
most conflict-affected area of the country, and help to restore access to basic social services 
and markets. An additional 110 kilometers (km) of national roads and 120 km of provincial roads 
in the Northern Province and the North Central Province (NCP) will be rehabilitated.3 It will 
facilitate economic growth and contribute to reducing disparities in Sri Lanka, in line with one of 
the Government of Sri Lanka’s key goals, which emphasizes equitable growth. 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  As Sri Lanka continues to absorb the benefits of the end of its 3-decade civil conflict in 
May 2009, the economy grew at a high rate of 8.3% in 2011. Among others, the Northern 
Province and its neighboring NCP are in the worst conflict-affected region in the country. With 
the normalization of the economic and social  environment, economic prospects in the two 
provinces demonstrate significant improvement. In 2010, the highest rate of growth (22.9%) was 
recorded in the Northern Province, and a similar rate (20.3%) in the NCP. However, regional 
disparity remains a feature of the economy. The share of gross domestic product is only 3.4% 
for the Northern Province and 4.8% for NCP—less than their share of the population. 
 
4.  Recognizing this, the government’s development strategy emphasizes equitable access 
to infrastructure and services for all, to promote inclusive growth.4 The sustainability of recent 
development outcomes is at risk if the road connectivity cannot be improved in a timely manner. 
Prolonged underinvestment during the conflict left the road network in a state of total disrepair. 
People in the region have poor and limited access to local markets and basic social services. 
Mobility between the Northern Province and southern regions requires substantial travel time 
owing to the inadequate condition of the linking arterial roads. Poor road connectivity in Northern 
Province and NCP has hindered the spread of economic activities and regional development. 
 
5.  In support of the government’s national strategy, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
approved loans on 18 June 2010 for the Northern Road Connectivity Project (footnote 2). The 
original project is rehabilitating about 170 km of national roads and 140 km of provincial roads in

$173 million. ADB finances the original project through (i) a loan of $130 million from its ordinary 
capital resources (OCR); and (ii) a loan of SDR16,080,000 ($24.4 million equivalent) from its 
Special Funds resources. The government finances $18.6 million of taxes and duties. The 
original project is performing well based on the following assessment:5  
(i)  Delivery of expected outputs. The delivery of expected outputs is satisfactory. 
The construction works on national roads, provincial roads, and the offices of the 
NPRDD  will  be  completed  by  March  2013,  and  will  be  followed  with  3-year 
performance-based maintenance of project roads. The original project is on track 
to meet the intended outcome of improved road connectivity within the Northern 
Province and with the southern region of the country. 
(ii)  Satisfactory  implementation  progress.  The  implementation  progress  is 
satisfactory. As of June 2012, all contracts have been awarded with a cumulative 
amount  of  $108.15  million  (104.5%  of  the  projection).  The  cumulative 
disbursement has reached $36.26 million (111.2% of the projection). 
(iii)  Satisfactory  compliance  with  safeguard  policy  requirements.  The 
compliance  with  safeguard  policy  requirements  of  the  original  project  is 
proceeding satisfactorily. 
(iv)  Successful management of risks. The risks have been successfully managed. 
The main lesson is that high implementation readiness will avoid delays for such 
a project in the post-conflict area. To address the risk of post-project operation 
and  maintenance,  provisions  of  3-year  performance-based  maintenance  are 
included in all contracts. A road maintenance scheme is being established in the 
Northern Province.6 
(v)  On  track  rating. The original project has been rated on track in the project 
performance rating for the last 12 months. 
 
6.  It is estimated that $20 million of proceeds of the original loan from ADB’s OCR will 
become  surplus.  To  cover  additional  geographical  areas  and  consolidate  the  development 
outcomes, the government has requested ADB to scale up the original project with the surplus 
and additional financing. The overall project meets eligibility criteria for additional financing,7 
which will help consolidate development outcomes by covering additional geographic areas and 
increasing project beneficiaries. The modality of additional financing will enhance the intended 
impact of the original project by utilizing the existing implementation arrangements to achieve 
results expeditiously. 
 
7.  The overall project, including the original project and the additional financing, is in line 
with  the  strategic  objective  in  ADB’s  country  partnership  strategy,  2012–2016  as  agreed 
between  the  government  and  ADB:  improving  connectivity  and  service  delivery  to  lagging 
regions, including the former conflict-affected regions of the country.8 The proposed additional 
financing is included in the country operations business plan, 2012–2014.9 In the future, ADB’s 
assistance will focus on (i) continuing to improve the road connectivity for the lagging regions 
and for important links, (ii) relieving the traffic congestion in the urban areas and on the trunk

B.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The overall project impact will remain—balanced and inclusive growth in the Northern 
Province. The overall project’s immediate outcome will be improved road connectivity within the 
Northern Province, and with the southern region of the country. 
 
C.  Outputs 
 
9.  With additional financing, the up-scaled project outputs are as follows: (i) about 280 km 
of national highways in the Northern Province and NCP are rehabilitated; (ii) about 260 km of 
provincial roads in the Northern Province and NCP are rehabilitated, and selected bridge links 
are rehabilitated or replaced; and (iii) the offices of the NPRDD are rehabilitated.10

11.  The government has requested an additional loan of $30 million from ADB’s OCR to help 
finance civil works of the national highway component; and an additional loan of SDR45,215,000 
($68 million equivalent) from ADB’s Special Funds resources to help finance civil works of the 
national highway component and provincial road component, consulting services, and project 
management.11 The government will finance taxes, duties, part of the road maintenance, and 
land acquisition and resettlement of about $14.80 million. 
 
12.  The loan from ADB’s OCR will have a 26-year term, including a grace period of 5 years, 
an annual interest rate determined in accordance with ADB’s London interbank offered rate 
(LIBOR)-based lending facility,12 a commitment charge of 0.15% per year (interest and other 
charges during construction to be capitalized in the loan), and such other terms and conditions 
set forth in the draft loan and project agreements. The government has provided ADB with (i) the 
reasons for its decision to borrow under ADB’s LIBOR-based lending facility based on these 
terms and conditions, and (ii) an undertaking that these choices were its own independent 
decision and not made in reliance on any communication or advice from ADB. 
 
13.  The loan from ADB’s Special Funds resources will have a 32-year term, including a 
grace period of 8 years, an interest rate of 1.0% per annum during the grace period and 1.5% 
per annum thereafter, and such other terms and conditions set forth in the draft loan and project 
agreements.

III.  TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
17.  In conjunction with the original project, associated TA has been provided to strengthen 
the capacity of the NPRDD on road asset management (footnote 2). The TA will be expanded to 
enhance the capacity of road agencies in road operation and maintenance by continuing the 
efforts of the original TA and previous TA in NCP.15 The TA will carry out the following additional 
activities: (i) building the capacity of NPRDD and NCPRDA in administering performance-based 
maintenance contracts with the road asset management system developed in previous TA; 
(ii) improving the awareness of the Road Development Authority (RDA), NPRDD, and NCPRDA 
on how to design and implement gender-inclusive road projects; and (iii) raising the awareness 
of road users through training on road safety, HIV/AIDS, and human trafficking. 
 
18.  The cost of additional TA activities is estimated at $1 million, which will be financed by 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). The government will provide office space 
and counterpart staff from RDA, NPRDD, and NCPRDA. The TA will provide required consultant 
input and necessary equipment and facilities. A consulting firm will be recruited to implement the 
TA. Individual consultants will be engaged as needed to facilitate the TA implementation. The 
consultant will be selected in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2010, as amended from time to time). Disbursement will be in accordance with ADB’s Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). About 58 person-
months  of  consulting  input  (22  international  and  36  national)  will  be  required.  The  TA 
implementation period is from January 2011 to December 2015.16 
 
IV.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Technical 
 
19.  The  engineering  design  has  been  carried  out  for  all  additional  project  roads  to  be 
financed, based on site condition surveys and field investigations.17 The required improvement 
works are optimized for economy and construction efficiency in accordance with applicable 
international  design  standards.  The  construction  method  will  utilize  proven  technology  with 
standard  materials  compatible  with  local  conditions.  All  civil  works  contracts  will  include 
rehabilitation of project roads and 5-year performance-based maintenance. The project roads 
have  been  assessed  for  climate  vulnerability  according  to  the  National  Climate  Change 
Adaptation Strategy for Sri Lanka.18 Key risks assessed include (i) shifting of climate zones, 
(ii) flood risk, (iii) landslides, (iv) sea level rise, and (v) drought exposure. The design of the 
project roads includes provisions for embankment rising and drainage enhancement. 
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
 
20.  The economic analysis was carried out in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for the 
Economic  Analysis  of  Projects.19 The  principal  benefits  calculated  are  savings  in  vehicle

from 17.3% to 24.1% for additional national roads (footnote 17). The overall EIRR for the 
national  roads  is  21.2%.  The  sensitivity  analysis  indicates  that  the  overall  national  road

12.1% to 36.3%. The overall EIRR for the provincial roads is 22.4%. The sensitivity analysis of 
the overall provincial roads resulted in an EIRR above 12%. Individually, a few provincial road 
sections may have an EIRR below 12% if there is an adverse variation in costs and benefits. 
However, the inclusion of these provincial road sections is considered appropriate because they 
provide essential accessibility to the rural and poor population in the interior areas. 
 
21.  The EIRRs of the national and provincial roads covered by the original project, additional 
scope,  and  both  combined  are  above  12%.  Therefore,  the  proposed  improvements  are 
economically  viable.  In  addition  to  the  quantified  benefits,  the  project  will  bring  significant 
benefits to the overall regional development. The project road will provide direct access to social 
services, such as education and health facilities. The industry development will also benefit from 
the improved national roads as the investment climate is upgraded by better connectivity to the 
supply sources and markets outside the region. While such benefits are not quantified, they are 
the project's contribution to economic development and poverty reduction. 
 
C.  Governance 
 
22.  Policy and legal. RDA, the implementing agency for the national road component, is 
responsible for the development and maintenance of the national highway network. RDA was 
established as a statutory authority with a separate legal personality by the Road Development 
Authority Act in 1981. RDA’s chairperson reports to the secretary of the Ministry of Ports and 
Highways (MOPH). 
 
23.  NPRDD, the implementing agency for the provincial road component in the Northern 
Province,is responsible for the Northern Province’s provincial road network in accordance with 
 
the 13th Amendment to the Constitution. The director of NPRDD reports to Northern Province's 
chief secretary through the secretary of the provincial Ministry of Infrastructure Development and 
Reconstruction. The Northern Province does not have an elected council. The chief secretary of 
the Northern Province, who has wide provincial administrative authority, will chair the project 
coordinating committee for monitoring provincial project implementation. 
 
24.  NCPRDA,  the  implementing  agency  for  the  provincial  road  component  in  NCP,  is 
responsible for managing provincial roads in NCP. It is established through a provincial statute 
as a separate legal entity operating within NCP. NCPRDA is headed by a board of directors, one 
of whom is appointed as the chairperson. 
 
25.  Institutional capacity. RDA and NCPRDA have sufficient capacity, past experience, 
and institutional strength to implement the project. NPRDD's capacity has been strengthened 
through implementing the provincial road component of the current project, and enhanced by the 
TA for capacity development of NPRDD. 
 
26.  Financial management. A financial management assessment was carried out for the 
implementing agencies—RDA, NPRDD, and NCPRDA. All implementing agencies have prior 
and ongoing experience of implementing ADB-funded projects and have satisfactory capacity in 
terms of project financial accounting and knowledge of ADB disbursement procedures. RDA and 
NPRDD have, and NCPRDA will soon establish a dedicated project accounting and finance

27.  Procurement and anticorruption. Procurement will be carried out in accordance with

the Declaration of Asset and Liabilities Act, No. 1 of 1975, and Permanent Commission to 
Investigate Allegations of Bribery and Corruption Act, No 19 of 1994 provide a legal basis to deal 
with bribery and corruption. The auditor general also monitors procurement of the agencies, with 
special attention to procedural propriety in procurement. ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as 
amended from time to time) was explained to and discussed with the government, MOPH, the 
Ministry of Local Government and Provincial Councils (MLGPC), RDA, NPRDD, and NCPRDA. 
The specific policy requirements and supplementary measures are in the PAM (footnote 13). 
 
D.  Poverty and Social 
 
28.  Poverty reduction and social impact. A poverty and social assessment of the project 
area found the project would provide communities with enhanced mobility and improved social 
interactions. The project will have a short-term impact on poverty reduction by employing local 
population. These opportunities will increase livelihood opportunities for those depending on 
occasional  employment.  Furthermore,  the  project  will  prove  access  to  new  economic  and 
employment  opportunities.  Improved  roads  will  help  the  rural  population  to  transport  their 
products to markets and obtain higher profit margins. It is estimated that 1.86 million people 
residing in five districts will benefit from the project. The contracts for civil works will include 
measures to ensure a safe and healthy working environment for both men and women labors. 
The contractors are required to comply with equal pay for equal work for men and women, 
health and safety at construction sites and labor camps, no child labor, and an awareness 
program for workers on the prevention of sexually transmitted infections.21 
 
29.  Gender. Sri Lanka ranks midway on the United Nations gender-related development 
index. However, in general, gender-related indicators in the northern and eastern parts of the 
country lag behind national levels. Women in project areas are frequent road users for family 
tasks. Improved road connectivity will provide better access to health services, higher levels of 
education, economic opportunities, and social interactions. Reduced travel time will result in 
more time on productive activities. No adverse impact on women was envisaged. A gender 
action  plan  has  been  prepared  for  the  project  to  (i)  maximize  women’s  access  to  project 
benefits, (ii) provide opportunities to increase women’s skills and income, and (iii) minimize 
social  vulnerability.  Practical  and  implementable  activities  have  been  incorporated.22 Key 
activities  include  (i)  involving  women  in  civil  works,  (ii)  ensuring  road  safety  awareness in 
roadside communities, (iii) providing a pedestrian- and cyclist-friendly design, and (iv) building 
the capacity of government agencies in improving gender-sensitivity of transport projects. A 
gender specialist will be engaged under the associated TA to support RDA, NCPRDA, and 
NPRDD in the overall implementation of the gender action plan. 
 
30.  HIV/AIDS. Sri Lanka has a low HIV prevalence rate although the number of reported 
cases has increased, in part because of improved access to testing facilities. Countrywide 
                                                 
21 Summary Poverty Reduction and Social Strategy (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
22 Gender Action Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

9 
responses have included the establishment of the National STD/AIDS Control Programme, 
which helps to refurbish health clinic and establish outreach and awareness programs. The 
project  has  incorporated  measures  to  mitigate  HIV/AIDS  risks,  by  undertaking  awareness 
programs for civil works contractors at construction sites, and for project-affected communities at 
prominent  village  locations.  Awareness-raising  activities  for  project-affected  persons  will  be 
conducted separately for men and women to address gender-specific issues. 
 
31.  Human  trafficking. Human trafficking is not a significant issue in the project area. 
Communities with young widows and orphaned children have been identified as potential risk 
groups. Awareness programs for human trafficking will be held in project-affected communities. 
 
E.  Safeguards 
 
32.  Involuntary resettlement. The project is classified category B. Road improvements are 
within the existing right-of-way (footnote 17). Limited land acquisition and resettlement will be 
required on one national highway (AB019). It is estimated that 37 households (151 persons) will 
be affected. The majority of these households will experience a limited impact, including loss of 
boundary walls, crops, and home gardens. One household, consisting of four persons, will lose 
more  than  10%  of  its  productive  assets.  One  resettlement  plan  has  been  prepared  in 
accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the Government of Sri Lanka’s Land 
Acquisition Act of 1950, and the National Involuntary Resettlement Policy introduced in 2001.23 
The Environmental and Social Division of RDA will implement the resettlement plan. 
 
33.  Indigenous  peoples.  The  project  is  not  expected  to  have  impacts  on  indigenous 
peoples and is classified category C. 
 
34.  Environment. The project is classified category B. None of the project roads are located 
inside  protected  areas  or  environmentally  sensitive  areas  (footnote  17).  Three  initial 
environmental examination reports together with environmental monitoring plans (EMPs) have 
been prepared for the national roads, northern provincial roads, and north central provincial 
roads. Contract package-specific EMPs have also been prepared. The requirements of the 
EMPs and of the conditional clearance provided by the Central Environmental Authority have 
been included in the bidding documents and as part of the contracts. Anticipated environmental 
impacts  include  small-scale  removal  of  trees;  occupational  health  and  safety  issues;  and 
generation of dust, noise, and drainage problems. These are mainly confined to the construction 
stage and can be addressed through mitigation measures. Details of consultations, feedback 
received, requirements for further consultation, and the grievance redress mechanism have 
been included in the initial environmental examination report.24  
 
35.  The Environmental and Social Division of RDA, assisted by the project implementation 
consultants, will monitor the implementation of the EMP for the national roads. The project 
implementation  units  of  the  NPRDD  and  NCPRDA  will  coordinate  and  monitor  the 
implementation of the social and environment safeguards for provincial roads, with support from 
the project implementation consultants. Training and coordination workshops on environment 
safeguards  and  EMP  implementation  will  be  conducted  for  implementing  agencies  and 
contractors,  as  necessary.  Environmental  monitoring  reports  will  be  prepared  annually  and 
submitted to ADB for disclosure on the ADB website, as required by ADB’s Safeguard Policy 
Statement for environment category B projects. 
                                                 
23 Resettlement Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
24 Initial Environmental Examination (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

10 
F.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
 
36.  The key risk is implementation delay. To mitigate the risk, detail design and bidding 
documents  have  been  prepared  in  advance  to  award  the  first  contract  shortly  upon  loan 
effectiveness. The overall risk assessment is medium without mitigation and low with mitigation. 
Integrated benefits and impacts are expected to outweigh costs. Major risks and mitigating 
measures are described in detail in the risk assessment and risk management plan.25  
 
V.  ASSURANCES 
 
37.  The government, MOPH, and MLGPC have assured ADB that implementation of the 
project shall conform to all applicable ADB policies and frameworks including those concerning 
anticorruption  measures,  safeguards,  gender,  procurement,  consulting  services,  and 
disbursement as described in detail in the PAM and loan documents. 
 
38.  The government, MOPH, and MLGPC have agreed with ADB on certain covenants for 
the project, which are set forth in the loan agreements and project agreements. 
 
VI.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
39.  I am satisfied that the proposed loans would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve 
(i)  the loan of $30,000,000 to the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka for the 
additional  financing  of  the  Northern  Road  Connectivity  Project,  from  ADB’s 
ordinary capital resources, with interest to be determined in accordance with 
ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility; for a term of 
26  years,  including  a  grace  period  of  5  years;  and  such  other  terms  and 
conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft loan 
and project agreements presented to the Board; and 
(ii)  the loan in various currencies equivalent to SDR45,215,000 to the Democratic 
Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka for the additional financing of the Northern Road 
Connectivity  Project,  from  ADB’s  Special  Funds  resources,  with  an  interest 
charge at the rate of 1.0% per annum during the grace period and 1.5% per 
annum thereafter; for a term of 32 years, including a grace period of 8 years; and 
such other terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set 
forth in the draft loan and project agreements presented to the Board. 
 
 
 
 
 
Haruhiko Kuroda 
President 
23 August 2012
